metadata.title: 5 Things To Know: July 18, 2025
metadata.description: CNBC’s Melissa Lee reports on the 5 things to know on July 18, 2025.

transcript.full_text: Five things to know ahead of today's opening bell. Recapping the breaking news from Becky at the top of the show, Chevron has prevailed in its mediation with Exxon over the Guyana oil assets. The decision clears the way for Chevron's acquisition of Hess. A look at Hess stock up 8 and a half% premarket, Chevron up 3.7%. Federal Reserve Chair Jay Powell formerly responding to questions from the White House about renovations to the Central Bank's DC headquarters. In a letter to the Office of Management and Budget, Powell provided details on project cost overruns. He's also batted down accusations that the renovated buildings will feature luxury amenities. The Financial Times reporting the valuation of AI startup Perplexity has risen 18 to $18 billion, two months after the company raised money at a $14 billion valuation. The paper says that after funding round closed, uh new investors approached Perplexity and were told they could purchase equity at the higher valuation level. And Amazon is laying off some staffers in its cloud computing division. A spokesperson said the cuts were not primarily due to investments in AI, but are a result of ongoing efforts to streamline the workforce and refocus on certain priorities. And the Commerce Department says it will impose anti-dumping duties of more than 90% on a type of graphite imported from China and used in making electric vehicle batteries. The government concluding the material is being sold in the US at less than fair market value.

analysis.summary:
The day's market opened with significant corporate and economic news. Chevron announced its success in mediation with Exxon concerning the highly contested Guyana oil assets, a resolution that clears the path for Chevron's planned acquisition of Hess. Following this news, Hess's stock saw a substantial premarket surge of 8.5%, while Chevron also experienced a positive uplift of 3.7%, indicating positive investor reception to the strategic development in the energy sector.

Further economic updates included Federal Reserve Chair Jay Powell's formal response to inquiries from the White House regarding the extensive renovations at the Central Bank's Washington D.C. headquarters. In a detailed letter to the Office of Management and Budget, Powell addressed concerns over project cost overruns. He also explicitly refuted allegations that the renovated facilities would incorporate luxury amenities, providing transparency on the expenditures.

In the tech sector, AI startup Perplexity's valuation remarkably jumped to $18 billion, a significant increase from its $14 billion valuation just two months prior. This rapid ascent occurred after its last funding round closed, attracting new investors willing to acquire equity at the higher valuation. Separately, Amazon announced layoffs within its cloud computing division. A company spokesperson clarified that these job cuts were primarily driven by efforts to streamline the workforce and refocus strategic priorities, rather than being a direct consequence of investments in artificial intelligence. Finally, the Commerce Department revealed its intent to impose anti-dumping duties exceeding 90% on graphite imported from China, a crucial material for electric vehicle batteries, after determining it was being sold in the U.S. below fair market value.

key_points.text: The broadcast highlights five key things to know ahead of the day's opening bell.
Chevron has successfully concluded its mediation with Exxon regarding the Guyana oil assets.
This decision by Chevron clears the path for its acquisition of Hess.
Hess stock saw a significant premarket increase of 8.5%.
Chevron's stock also rose by 3.7% in premarket trading.
Federal Reserve Chair Jay Powell formally responded to questions from the White House.
The questions concerned renovations to the Central Bank's DC headquarters.
Powell provided details on project cost overruns in a letter to the Office of Management and Budget.
He refuted accusations that the renovated buildings would feature luxury amenities.
The Financial Times reported on the valuation of AI startup Perplexity.
Perplexity's valuation has risen to $18 billion.
This valuation increase occurred two months after the company was valued at $14 billion.
New investors approached Perplexity after its funding round closed.
These investors were told they could purchase equity at the higher $18 billion valuation.
Amazon is implementing layoffs within its cloud computing division.
An Amazon spokesperson stated the cuts were not primarily due to investments in AI.
The layoffs are a result of ongoing efforts to streamline the workforce.
The layoffs also aim to refocus on certain priorities within Amazon's cloud computing.
The Commerce Department plans to impose anti-dumping duties.
The duties will be more than 90% on a specific type of graphite.
This graphite is imported from China.
The graphite is used in making electric vehicle batteries.
The U.S. government concluded the graphite is being sold at less than fair market value.
The mediation between Chevron and Exxon specifically concerned oil assets.
The Central Bank's headquarters are located in Washington, D.C.
Perplexity is identified as an AI startup.
Perplexity's previous funding round valued the company at $14 billion.
Perplexity's current reported valuation is $18 billion.
The Amazon layoffs are specifically targeting its cloud computing division.
The Commerce Department's duties are focused on graphite imports.
The graphite subject to duties is specifically used in EV battery manufacturing.

timeline_events.event_description: Announcement of 'Five things to know ahead of today's opening bell', setting the context for current and immediate future news.
Recap of 'breaking news' from Becky, suggesting recent and significant developments.
Chevron prevailed in its mediation with Exxon over Guyana oil assets.
The mediation decision clears the way for Chevron's acquisition of Hess.
Federal Reserve Chair Jay Powell formally responded to questions from the White House regarding renovations to the Central Bank's DC headquarters.
Powell provided details on project cost overruns in a letter to the Office of Management and Budget.
Powell batted down accusations that the renovated buildings will feature luxury amenities.
The valuation of AI startup Perplexity has risen to $18 billion.
Perplexity raised money at a $14 billion valuation (occurred two months prior to the $18B valuation).
New investors approached Perplexity after its funding round closed.
Investors were told they could purchase equity at the higher valuation level.
Amazon is laying off some staffers in its cloud computing division.
The Commerce Department will impose anti-dumping duties of more than 90% on graphite imported from China.
The government concluded that graphite imported from China is being sold in the US at less than fair market value.

temporal_patterns.description: A progression of valuation for the AI startup Perplexity, rising from $14 billion to $18 billion over a two-month period.
temporal_patterns.significance: Illustrates rapid growth in company valuation.

temporal_patterns.description: A causal chain where Chevron's prevailing in mediation leads directly to the clearance for its acquisition of Hess.
temporal_patterns.significance: Outlines a direct cause-and-effect relationship in corporate actions.

temporal_patterns.description: Amazon's workforce adjustments are described as 'ongoing efforts' to streamline and refocus, indicating a continuous process rather than a one-time event.
The Commerce Department's conclusion about unfair market value for graphite serves as the justification for a future action: imposing anti-dumping duties.
temporal_patterns.significance: Explains the rationale behind an impending government policy.
temporal_patterns.timespan: Immediate conclusion leading to future action
